subject: Re: [junit] Reporting historical test results

Yes,...how do you appropriately convey drooling in an e-mail.  Clover is our dream state, but it is more expensive than our management is willing to pay right now.  :)

-------------- Original message -------------- 
Diane,

You may want to use XSL and XSLT... Print out your Junit reports into
and XML format (<format />) and then use a standalone Java program or
any other tool to transform the XML into excel sheets. I know that it
is not too tough to make comma seperated .csv files from XML/XSL. I am
not too sure what will it take to create the binary .xls files.

as far as "velocity" factor you mentioned, take a look at section
4.3.2 of the book JUnit in Action. That refers to a tool called Clover
- never used it  - but sounds like what you are looking for.

hope this helps.


On Wed, 12 Jan 2005 15:16:09 +0000, didoss@...
<didoss@...> wrote:
> Paul -
> 
> Thanks for the reply.  Unfortunately, we are already doing that.
> 
> We run a nightlybuild with tests.  It copies the previous results to a
> backup-reports directory, cleans the reports directory, and then creates the
> current results html files.  Then, we send out an e-mail to the team, with
> the links to the various reports (for different 'chunks' of code), both
> current and previous.
> 
> Every morning, I am opening those reports and copying the highest level data
> (from the summary section -> #tests, #failures, #errors) into an excel
> spreadsheet.
> 
> Currently, we are trying to get our testing back under control - many
> iterations of allowing people to say their stories were complete without
> appropriate - or even working - tests.  Additionally, in the past, we have
> found that we have a velocity treshhold - after which our testing goes
> downhill.  So, we have a need to maintain this historical information, over
> the life of the project.
> 
> I am looking for a way to automate this.  What I'm thinking of is:
> when the reporting functionality totals the summary numbers, it could also
> output to another file type (ideally, straight into an excel spreadsheet;
> minimally, into a file that can be used as a data source for a spreadsheet)
> a configurable data set: date, time, #tests, #failures, #errors, #time.
> 
> Dianne
> 
> -------------- Original message -------------- 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Dianne Doss asked
> 
> 
> Is there an automated way to output the summary data (#tests,
> #errors, #failures) from my JUnit Report to an external file
> (possibly xls, or a file accessible by spreadsheet) in order to
> maintain a history of our results?
> 
> In the ideal world, there would never be any errors or failures, but
> the point of the testing is to make us confident in making code
> changes.  We run a nightlybuild regression, so the next morning I
> can see if I missed anything (sometimes the failures are well
> removed from the actual class that was changed).
> 
> So, we would like to be able to record historical data of the
> fluctuations.  In the past, manually, we have found that the
> errors/failures go up when we get above a certain velocity.
> 
> Thanks for any insight that can be provided.
> 
> Dianne Doss
> 
> 
> Dear Doss,
> 
>               If you are generating JUnit Report through Ant, definitely you
> should write one build.xml file. Before generating new report, why not you
> take copy of the previous report.  In Ant API  contains copy tag and move
> tag. So
> first step you take a back up using Copy/ Move tag.
> Second step you clear your old report using delete tag.
> Third step create report folder again.
> Finally you generate new report.
> 
> 
> 
> Paul Domnic J.
